title: What will be the closing price of Tesla stock on 31 December 2020?
preds: As of 11 Dec, stock sits at $608.

Currently the stock is over $600 and is being added to the S&P on Dec 21 
These seems to suggest a price squeeze upwards as passive indices bulk up on purchases into this cap-weighted index.
Nevertheless-  keeping a 1% chance of something going wrong is just a reminder to myself not to believe my own rationales unconditionally.

Elon Musk warns employees Tesla's stock could 'get crushed like a soufflé under a sledgehammer' - CNN
https://www.cnn.com/2020/12/02/business/elon-musk-tesla-stock-price/index.html
Wed, 02 Dec 2020 14:19:00 GMT In separate comments Tuesday, Musk repeated a statement he has made previously that the Tesla stock price is "too high."
"I even said the stock was too high. I mean what am I supposed to do," he said while rolling his eyes during an interview with Mathias Doepfner, CEO of technology and media company Axel Springer. Musk was responding to the fact that Tesla is worth more than five times as much as Volkswagen (VLKAF), the world's largest automaker in terms of sales.

Tesla recalls 9,500 Model X and Model Y cars over roof, bolt issues - CNBC
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/25/tesla-recalls-9500-model-x-and-model-y-cars-over-roof-bolt-issues.html
Wed, 25 Nov 2020 14:25:00 GMT
> Tesla is recalling more than 9,500 of its Model X and Model Y electric vehicles over potentially faulty roof trim and bolts that could be inadequately tightened.
> The company’s stock dipped slightly early Wednesday before trading up more than 1%.
> In October, Tesla voluntarily recalled nearly 50,000 Model S and Model X cars in China over faulty suspensions. Earlier this month, Tesla expanded its warranty to cover defective main computers in some Model S and Model X computers that led to touch screen blackouts, among other problems.
> Consumer Reports said Nov. 19 in its annual Auto Reliability Survey that it’s no longer recommending the Tesla Model S due to issues with its air suspension, main computer and touch controls. It also panned the Model Y’s body hardware and paint problems and ultimately gave three of four Tesla vehicles subpar reliability ratings, including the Model S, Model X and Model Y. Interesting.
"There will not be adjustments made for any stock split." --> And yet it's still over $400. Crazy!

US stocks severely overbought near term after an unprecedented rally from March lows. Double dip recession risk is high. Tech stocks in general look quite frothy... UST’s, gold, and USD are all waving red flags to risk assets... I think Tesla will have a trip to its March lows in this window. Chart shows potential double top. At same time, addition to SP500 was one of those classic “top” events, as stock price surged. I never like a stock after it has seen its price go straight up... This one is due for a correction, and a nasty one at that...
Being added to the S&P 500 seems to be a boost https://electrek.co/2020/11/18/tesla-tsla-surges-record-high-mysterious-investor-buying-big/
Being included in the S&P 500 index changes everything

Tesla (TSLA) surges on finally getting greenlight to join S&P500 - Electrek.co
https://electrek.co/2020/11/16/tesla-tsla-surges-greenlight-sp500/
Mon, 16 Nov 2020 22:39:00 GMT

TSLA is joining the S&P500, which could give the recently lagging stock a boost.  I'll throw in the towel and go with the crowd.  BTW, kudos to those who never wavered.  ... But then again it ain't over 'til it's over.
Adjusting for potential concerns of Elon's covid

What’s Tesla’s Problem? Hint: It’s Ours, Too - CleanTechnica
https://cleantechnica.com/2020/11/13/whats-teslas-problem-hint-its-ours-too/
Sat, 14 Nov 2020 03:38:54 GMT Volkswagen Accelerates Investment in Electric Cars as It Races to Overtake Tesla - The Wall Street Journal
https://www.wsj.com/articles/volkswagen-accelerates-investment-in-electric-cars-as-it-races-to-overtake-tesla-11605283260
Fri, 13 Nov 2020 16:01:00 GMT Ford is 'absolutely' interested in producing EV batteries like Tesla and GM - CNBC
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/13/ford-is-absolutely-interested-in-producing-ev-batteries-like-tesla-and-gm.html
Fri, 13 Nov 2020 17:12:00 GMT

Tesla expands warranty to cover defective main computers in some Model S and X vehicles - CNBC
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/09/tesla-will-refund-owners-who-paid-to-fix-main-computers-out-of-pocket.html
Tue, 10 Nov 2020 05:57:00 GMT

There are reports that sales in China have been disappointing.  Will this poke a hole in the balloon?  Maybe yes, maybe no.  I'll move a few chips to lower brackets. https://seekingalpha.com/article/4387842-tesla-china-growth-struggles?

I've learned a couple of lessons by trying to forecast stock prices on GJOpen. 1) Never short an "overpriced stock."  It may eventually go down, but you can't predict when.
2) Buy broad index ETFs, like VTI and IEFA, not individual companies.  The risk/reward ratio is better.

Toyota president: Tesla has 'not created a real business in the real world yet' - CNBC
https://www.cnbc.com/2020/11/06/toyota-president-tesla-valuation-doesnt-reflect-real-world-business.html
Fri, 06 Nov 2020 22:46:00 GMT Tesla just rolled out its own tequila. It's already sold out - CNN
https://www.cnn.com/2020/11/06/tech/tesla-tequila-nosotros-intl-hnk/index.html
Fri, 06 Nov 2020 08:17:00 GMT

TSLA didn't stay below $400 for long; it seems to be resuming its uptrend.  Based on the usual metrics it is very overvalued.  But as  John Maynard Keynes reportedly said, "The market can remain irrational longer than you can remain solvent."  Betting against TSLA on GJOpen is like shorting the stock, but with no real money on the line.

'I'm not drunk, it's my car:' Tesla's 'full self-driving' gets mixed reviews - CNN
https://www.cnn.com/2020/10/30/cars/tesla-full-self-driving/index.html
Fri, 30 Oct 2020 19:30:00 GMT

Price just dropped below $400, the company is still over-valued given its current assets and competitive advantage in the electric vehicle market (in my opinion anyway) and the economy is tanking. The question for me now is not if it will continue to decline but how low it will ultimately go given that it is largely a speculative stock that most investors wouldn't purchase in a bad or even worsening economy.

So many things have to go well for Tesla to have a market value of $400B.  Of course I could be wrong, and TSLA could simply regain it's upward momentum.  The crowd has never wavered from that opinion.  The next two months will be interesting in so many ways.

As Tesla full self-driving goes beta, Autopilot is rated a 'distant second' to GM's Super Cruise - ZDNet
https://www.zdnet.com/article/as-tesla-full-self-driving-goes-beta-autopilot-is-rated-a-distant-second-to-gms-super-cruise/
Thu, 29 Oct 2020 13:33:00 GMT
TSLA closed at $406 today, only 1.5% above $400.  I'll move a little further away from the crowd.

So, it looks like all the good news isn't enough to keep TSLA price up. Gradual slide, prelude to collapse or just some tweaking before the march up continues? Who knows? At the same time, the day is not over - after initial slide, the price is going up...
9 weeks more to wonder how that can be happening?

Increasing second highest bucket because it's less than a 3% decrease from current price to drop below 400. This article takes a more long-term view, but still has some interesting thoughts: 
https://www.forbes.com/sites/greatspeculations/2020/10/15/telsa-downside-how-tesla-stock-could-fall-below-150/#21e8282e24f7
Price is $ 444 today and stock is volatile.

Median of analysts 346, and usually they are too optimistic. But this stock gets people so emotional, that it might close at (imo ridiculously high) prices above 400$. https://money.cnn.com/quote/forecast/forecast.html?symb=tsla#
I am not crazy - just plugging in what the options market thinks (i.e. implied volatility via December put prices @ 447). https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/TSLA/options/
I submit to the Musk Reality Distortion Field.
Throwing in the towel.  TSLA only goes up, no matter what else happens.
Hedging a lot more; I've been very pessimistic vis a vis the crowd.  If TSLA punches above $450 I'll throw in the towel and go all in for "More than $400."

Here's some interesting reporting from the BBC: Are shares in Elon Musk’s Tesla vastly overvalued? (https://www.bbc.co.uk/sounds/play/w3cszl41) They might be right in the long run, but we're only concerned with what happens before the end of Dec. If this were a three-year prediction, I might weight it very differently. Just for pure entertainment,  at 16:27 you can listen to an investment fund manager attempting to explain away his fund's decision to sell Tesla stocks whilst simultaneously boosting them. Some sort of weird reverse sunk cost fallacy?
Currently at 441. -1% to 300-350, +1% to more than 400.
Scientific fact: Tesla defies gravity. At least for quite a while. Adjusting accordingly.

I generally don't practice the art of "technical analysis," i.e., using price history to predict future stock prices.  But I do look at charts, and they are frequently interesting even if not predictive.  I don't know what the pattern is called (maybe a pennant?) but the TSLA price is generally in a steep uptrend.  But it has approached $450 a couple of times and failed to punch through.  That, I believe is called a "resistance level." So I'll continue to watch the price action.  If TSLA rises above $450 I'll change my bearish bet, which heavily overweights $300-400.  Until then I'll bet on a correction.

Despite record production, super-ambitious year end targets, an anticipated Biden EV boom and the halo of battery day, Tesla is not really joining in the Nasdaq rebound. Given that their biggest independent shareholder Baillie Gifford has cashed in a few days before the September sell-off, I do not feel like Tesla can sustain this level until the end of the year. It's now mainly "suckers" holding the bag, not the kind of investors who can stomach a 1065 price earnings ratio if there is a "limit down" event. This is at this stage purely a gut feeling, not anything I have meticulously pieced together from tail hedge pricing or order book dynamics or anything of that sort. But it could be rewarding both financially and Brier-wise to dig deeper. Any strong views for / against?
Record production and deliveries?  Well, it may go up... or may go down?  Whatever emotions take over the market - fear to miss out. Or fear of sky high evaluations collapsing...
Hedging a bit, I still think a drop is likely at some point, just unclear if it will be before year end.

Tesla announced record Q3 deliveries, and the stock ... fell about 4%.  After exponential price increases reality often returns with a vengeance, and investors take profits.  With a market cap of over $400B there is a lot of good news already priced in. I'll go against the crowd, and bet that TLSA will end the year below $400/share.  But I won't predict a crash to below $300 either.  No guts, no glory.  This should be interesting.
I've just noticed the 11 August note that no adjustments will be made for stock splits. That's a pretty $hitty way of handling this question, imho.
TSLA is going up. You can easily find an explanation for that. If it goes down, there are readily available explanations for that too... ;) matter of faith, I guess.
Q3 ends tomorrow.  When Tesla releases sales data the answer to this question will become clearer.  If Tesla doesn't disappoint the crowd will have been right.  I'll move closer to the crowd.
TSLA is holding up well, so moving closer to the crowd.

Tesla continues to have a P/E ratio over 1000 without turning a profit in any fiscal year since it went public. That just isn't sustainable. Since it's split, the price has dropped (though not as drastically as I initially thought) but it is unlikely it will go anywhere but down as the economy continues to slow and a contentious election approaching.
Will 3 months be enough for TSLA  get closer reflect fundamentals? Most probably not. So for me better to get closer to the crowd.
Updating to reflect roughly what the options market thinks about Tesla. Up to 422 again pre-market, but that's not very meaningful for a stock that can go up $200 in 3 weeks..

TSLA is above $400 again.  The crowd is betting heavily that it will still be there on 12/31.  I'll bet on some kind of correction in the price.  Tesla may eventually have a $25,000 car, and they may increase battery production by a factor of 10 or more, but such endeavors take a long time.  They also cost a lot of money, and don't have high profit margins.  So put me down as a fan who is optimistic for the company, just not that optimistic.
Moving slightly away from over $400 because it's looking like the market may be beginning to correct for the excessive gains since March.
It seems the disappointment about Tesla is limited and, after trading at as low as 360 USD, it will hit 400USD again soon.

9/23 down 10% to $380. When have "fundamentals" influenced TSLA? Maybe 3 years ago at the latest. It's about sizzle and Battery Day fizzled as a main course. However, if production and sales keep up their current pace, that may be all the sizzle the market needs.

As @ThWedler just pointed out, fundamentals may be catching up with TSLA.  The crowd is still all in, with 98% betting on "more than $400."  I think it's time for a little humility regarding the future price of the stock.  The herd may be right.  But with 99 days to go anything could happen, so I'll spread out my bets. FWIW, personally I'm rooting for Tesla, I have never owned the stock (sadly), and I would like to buy a Model Y next year.

Fundamentals begin to (ever so slightly) catch up with Tesla's valuation.
https://www.marketwatch.com/story/teslas-stock-skids-5-as-promised-battery-day-innovations-remain-off-in-the-future-2020-09-22
It looks I may have been right on my Battery Day prediction "Buy the rumor, sell the news".

It seems TSLA's and E Musk's honeymoon period granted by the market is running out, expectations before the so called "battery day" were so high that it was hardly possible not to disappoint them. Analyst's judgment is unflattering: 
"Battery development is the key focus for investors, but the company failed to excite everyone.
'Nothing Musk discussed about batteries is a done deal. There was nothing tangible,' Roth Capital Partners analyst Craig Irwin told Reuters."
https://news.sky.com/story/what-did-elon-musk-say-to-make-tesla-shares-drop-by-50bn-12079327
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-22/musk-says-tesla-plans-25-000-electric-car-in-about-three-years

I have no idea what's behind 300% TSLA rise in the past 6 month, going from $150 in March of 2020 (pre-coronaviris) to around $450 yesterday while US has been in recession but I imagine that probably won't last because everything connects to everything else.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2020-09-22/tesla-bear-says-battery-day-all-smoke-and-mirrors-video Dance as long as the music plays...
+13 to over $400, depleting some of the lower end tail possibilities.
Currently at 448. -1% to less than 250, -1% to250-300, -3% to 300-350, -9% to 350-400, +14% to more than 400.

I a little puzzled by the choice of possible answers.  But I guess 11 August was when Tesla was still about $1000 before the split.  For the rest of August the price shot up to nearly $2000 before split.  Seems like good bet above $400, but with Tesla there is always a chance it could drop quickly.
Surrendering and moving closer to the ridiculous prices.
Going with the crowd on this one.
Over 400 now. Probably the horizon for a vaccine will be closer so even if shut-downs happen because people are spreading disease inside it is likely the clouds will be lifting.
Updating with a slight bearish twist.  the runup was too fast and high, very emotional lacking fundamentals.  Temporary?  we shall see.
Skewing toward over 400 (+20 to that category). Not sure if the big tech stocks can continue to maintain what looks to me like inflated values over the next few months but maybe they can.
Shifting slightly towards bin 5. If people are willing to pay more than 400$, I need to react.
TSLA price +9% up to 459 ... meeting the crowd for now
Although it might be ridiculously expensive, people are still buying the stock. I can´t ignore the current price, although I´d never pay it myself.

Illuminating discussion at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1132146 with @cafebedouin, thanks! Maybe Tesla's electronic equipment and big data do comprise a moat to take over the market with self-driving cars. I am not sure it justifies the stratospheric share price though. Will hope to include Tesla in S&P 500 keep the price climbing? It looks - may be yes, may be not:
https://cleantechnica.com/2020/09/11/tesla-tsla-isnt-in-the-sp-500-now-what/ The Battery Day? It may be "Buy on the rumor, sell on the news" thing. Still, I need to adjust for optimism of some dedicated investors. And "don't fight the tape"... PS: I should admit that I made some money by shorting Tesla a couple years ago. Most probably, it does serve as a positive affirmation of my disbelief in the Tesla's meteoric rise.

Everything is possible with this stock... What is interesting that, despite the influx of forecasts with predictions of much lower stock prices, the consensus hasn't budged. I guess many people are not paying attention to GJOP announcement about the split. I doubt they thought that TSLA would be $2,000/a share a few months ago.
$384 right now. New truck is popular so probably hit that above $400 mark. Hedging a little for now.

Adjusting for development after the stock split. A market dip due to a second COVID-19 wave (scare) of minus 20-30+% seems possible, but not very likely at this stage, therefore hedging into the lower buckets a little.
adjusting my shift in position after not reading the dates and panicking.

Most of the recent forecasts have moved away from a near-100% prediction of "More than $400."  One exception is @cdob63, who today went all in for the >$400 outcome.  I suspect that many people just haven't checked their predictions recently. But the markets are rallying today, and a move back above $400 cannot be ruled out, IMHO.  I think I was hasty yesterday when I lowered the >$400 prediction to 19%.  @cdob63 may have it right, along with the crowd.  So I am moving closer to the herd, but hedging a bit towards lower numbers.

+5 to 350 to 400. +7 to 300 to 350. It definitely seems overvalued, but bubbles can persist (it's been called overvalued for years). Recent weakening in the tech stocks that are propping up the S&P 500 has resulted in a drop, but hard to say if that's a trend or just a recent dip. The recent increase in tech stock valuations looked like a bubble to me and opposed to the reality of the unemployment situation, but again, bubbles are difficult to identify and can be unpredictable.
Tesla's stock split... almost literally Deus ex Machina for the forecasters bearish on this topic.

Adjusting forecast ..Will revisit in a couple of days https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-09-08/tesla-shares-slump-as-s-p-500-inclusion-remains-elusive https://money.cnn.com/quote/forecast/forecast.html?symb=tsla#
If the bubble started deflating, it is hard to stop...
Has the bubble started deflating? It seems like a possibility

Stock split dropped the price to around 300, but inflated it to closer to $500 with increased accessibility. Now in a downward spiral and still claims a P/E ratio over 900 (25 or lower is ideal). Most stocks are also currently dropping and looking back Tesla's stock averaged closer to $50/share (applying the stock split retroactively) for years before the 2020 surge. With a little under 4 months left and the heavy losses its recording on a daily basis it is most likely regressing to the mean. Also, bear in mind that Tesla has not recorded an annual profit yet and is unlikely to do so in 2020, so if a recession does grip the economy it will drop more than most given its current P/E ratio signaling its investors are growth/speculative spenders.

It looks like Tesla fans should have paid more attention to Elon Musk's tweet, when he said the stock price was too high.  I plan to buy a Model Y one day, so count me as a fan of the car.  But the stock always seemed risky. I don't have a high confidence as to what the price will be on Dec 31.  It's time to spread out the bets.

Usually if an analyst says "hold" he means, that you should better sell (18/32 say so). If they say "underperform" (3/37) it usually means, that you should sell NOW. If they say "sell" (8/38), it means, that you´re a total fool, if you haven´t sold yet.
.
"The 32 analysts offering 12-month price forecasts for Tesla Inc have a median target of 297.50, with a high estimate of 800.00 and a low estimate of 19.00. The median estimate represents a -28.79% decrease from the last price of 417.79."
From:
https://money.cnn.com/quote/forecast/forecast.html?symb=tsla#
Gah, should have spotted the dilution. At least it is now an interesting question.

Currently at 391. +2% to <250, +3% to 250-300, +5% to 300-350, +5% to 350-400, -15% to >400. S&P decided NOT to add Tesla to the index this September. 11 trillion or so currently tracks the S&P500, TSLA at its current valuation would eventually get a ~1.5% weighting in the index. That's alot of money the market was expecting to be directed towards TSLA in September. https://amp-cnn-com.cdn.ampproject.org/v/s/amp.cnn.com/cnn/2020/09/04/investing/tesla-sp-500-etsy/index.html?amp_js_v=a3&amp_gsa=1&usqp=mq331AQFKAGwASA%3D#aoh=15993083278459&referrer=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.google.com&amp_tf=From%20%251%24s&ampshare=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cnn.com%2F2020%2F09%2F04%2Finvesting%2Ftesla-sp-500-etsy%2Findex.html

We all (ok, most of us) know it is irrationally high price. Can it hold? Maybe. Can it lose most of its value? Possible. Can it double the price/ Yep. It is shooting in the dark. One way out of this mess is just to follow the crowd (currently 99% in the highest bucket).  Another is to use your head. The last one is dangerous, but exciting!

Stock split means shares are now in the mid-$400 range instead of over $1000. Moreover, it hit a low of $408 today after dropping over 15% at one point, meaning it was very close to dropping below the $400 mark. While daily fluctuations do not mean much in the longterm, the fact that one can be so extreme is cause for concern. More importantly, however, the tech boom that reinvigorated the market months ago is beginning to cool and Tesla's current P/E ratio is over 1100, which is insane. This essentially means that the yearly earnings available to shareholders are more than 1000 times lower than the price of each stock. Most savvy investors look for stocks with P/E ratios closer to 10-15 and avoid those over 25. Name recognition and its past performance could keep the price up for a while, but its likely to come crashing down sooner or later. In reality, Tesla hasn't turned a profit in any of the last 4 fiscal years, so its current investors are really banking on the future. If the market crashes, however, I think Tesla falls hard and fast.
Currently at 502 with 4months to go. -1% to less than 250, -3% to 250-300, -4% to 300-350, -4% to 350-400, +12% to 400.
It´s insane, but it happens anyway...
I am sticking to the highest bucket, but should note that it is utterly unfair to keep the same target after 5 for 1 split.
Tesla is at 465, continuing to trend up. -1% to 300-35, -2% to 350-400, +3% to 'More than $400'

While Nikkei Business Publications gave Tesla a six-year lead in electronics relative to Toyota and VW, I think the technological advantage might be overstated and not justify a 900% year-on-year increase of its share price. I think there is a decent probability of competitors to catch up as well as new players like Lucid to emerge. (Lucid provided the battery packs for the entire Formula-E Championship)
https://www.caranddriver.com/news/a33797162/2021-lucid-air-517-mile-range-113-kwh-battery/
Tesla and Panasonic also seem to have not as a synergetic partnership as it seems.
Redoing my base rate due to the 5:1 stock split.

Usually I don´t believe the anaylsts, but this time I think, they are right. This stock is too expensive. It´s a great company, building wonderful cars, but the stock price is ridiculously high.  https://money.cnn.com/quote/forecast/forecast.html?symb=tsla#
Adjusting based on current high and passage of time.

More or less gambling along with many others on this stock's (post-split) price, at this point https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/24/apple-and-tesla-have-long-term-upside-after-stock-splits-jim-cramer-says.html

And now it's up to $2,153.17 before the split, so $430.63 after-split. There's nothing that actually justifies TSLA being up 900% over the last 52 weeks and having the #10 market cap in the world. It is the biggest single-company bubble in stock market history. The trouble is predicting when the bubble will burst.  Before or after December 31st?

Tech sector accounted for around 25% of overall rebound in stock market, meaning many stocks are likely overvalued due to federal support and subsidies. That being said, the current price seems stable at well above $400 and it is unlikely the economy will be even worse in coming months, though we may begin seeing more of the impact of current struggles soon.

Sheesh. Tesla getting valued as the #11 company in the world ( https://www.dogsofthedow.com/largest-companies-by-market-cap.htm ) is utterly insane, and yet that's what the current price is. I don't know, I just . . . seriously?
Rising towards $400 again when stock is split.

The momentum is too great. Don't fight the tape and don't fight the Fed, both are conspiring to drive this higher.
If Berlin is open for business in December, even if not in production, the stock will be higher still. If Shanghai is producing MY by year end, ditto.
Not adjusting for split really throws the whole question off. Scores are going to be jacked up, I doubt anyone was anticipating a split early on. Oh well I suppose.

I didn't realise when I made my forecast that stock splits would not be taken into consideration - in future maybe that should be made clear. the "Tesla stock" at the start of the forecast is NOT the same as the "Tesla stock" after a stock split. Meanwhile, back in the real world, TSLA is likely to be added to the S&P500 and Giga Berlin is running well ahead of Giga Shanghai and "Battery Day" should provide continued price momentum.
Sticking with the $400.
Price increase significant today, likely to increase significantly prior to the 31 Aug stock split. Therefore, falling back into the >$400 arena.
Ok, Ok, I'll join the "400 club" again.
Another big price run-up, prior to the stock split... https://thenextweb.com/hardfork/2020/08/18/tesla-apple-stock-split-rally-pump-investor-traders-share-price-down/
This is insane. We are climbing back to $400 at record pace.

Aug 14 Split adjusted close = $330 in a wild ride of a week. Announce a split and your stock jumps 10%. Not a bad return on capital. Now if Battery Day goes extremely well and the Solar business looks sound the 350 price may be justified. If Battery Day is percieved as hype, things could deflate. 5 weeks to go to find out.

OK, so I guess that the terse GJP update stating that "there will not be adjustments made for any stock split" means that forecasters must now account for the impending split in their forecasts.  Attempting to do so... https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/12/investing/stock-split-apple-tesla/index.html
It´s a cool company, but it has been overprized before the latest increase already.

Truely amazing shot in the arm from the stock split, $400 is not out of the question.
Aug 13 up 5% on no news, 1,644.58USD which is about $320 for this contest.
By the way, whatever asshole decided that splits would not be adjusted for should be punched in the teeth.

Well there goes the Brier, right into the toilet on this one. Who knows maybe Elon can pull off another miracle and salvage our Briers. Go buy a Tesla right now and we maybe can still hit the $400 mark by year end. Today's post split price is $296, post split stocks usually climb a bit more. Unfortunately, Berlin and Austin won't be running by year end, but Model Y in Shanghai might be further along.

Well, now that it's been declared there won't be any adjustments for a stock split, there's a bit more uncertainty, isn't there? If Musk decides he wants to split twelve-for-one, the consensus is screwed.
It's almost $1500 now. Hasn't been under $400 since last year and unlikely to return there within the next four months.
If there was a 3 for 1 stock split, it would still be in the top bucket.
It is likely that it goes down, but very unlikely that it go down lower than 400$ due to the increasing demand for electric vehicles, though the coronavirus could brake their development.
Decent chance it will pull back from current levels but I don't see a a scenario with a greater than .4% chance that will cause it to break below 400.

Stocks are fluctuating, yet this is not a specific concern for Tesla, just general COVID economic concerns. Therefore, unlikely that a company which reported its fourth straight quarterly profit and making it eligible for inclusion in the S&P 500 index is likely to drop share-price in the near future. Source: https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/24/tesla-shares-slide-as-traders-take-profits-from-2020s-high-flying-stocks.html
Update for passing time. Reducing time spent for forecasting for a while.
Something catastrophic would need to occur at this stage.
Apologies for another forecast. Just getting my foot in the game for stock forecast.
One thing I can be 100% certain of us I will always get Tesla wrong! Constantly underestimating

Due to momentum and market sentiment, Tesla Inc. will continue to appear a success story. Financials are weak and fixed capital investment is costly, but will not become an issue. Tesla could easily raise new equity through different channels, when hostile takeovers may become interesting in the industry. Similar to Apple earlier, Tesla understands to engage the media for its purposes and has hardly any cost for marketing and nevertheless much attention in the news. Its premium only-strategy seems to work out: product pricing is still in the upper range on average, still the product appears desirable to customers. Electrification, digitalisation and expansion of mobile communications into every aspect of everyday life promises lots of opportunities for secondary businesses.
It is, due to past squeezes in Tesla stock, at present more of a risk NOT to be invested in Tesla for large and institutional investors, which lays a floor at, say, 300USD.

Possible regulatory issues and actions with governments (especially in Europe) is the largest downside risk, but so far Tesla has been treated very benevolent. Moreover, Teslas success seems to be of special interest and under protection of the US government.

Currently at $767.29, barring a major catastrophe or acquisition, slipping below $400 would be a massive downturn.

People have covered shorts (and lost). Many have also made tidy sum. From WalL Street Journal: “Fred Lande’s heart was pounding as he watched Tesla Inc. shares charge to an all-time high of $968.99 last week. It wasn’t because he was happy.
He’d bet thousands of dollars that the frantic rally that has more than tripled the price of the shares in just a few months was doomed to end, and soon. Concluding his gamble was wrong, he closed the options trade at a loss. “Someone could go buy a brand new Toyota Camry with the loss that I took,” said Mr. Lande, who frequently trades for his personal account and runs a chat room for retail stock traders. Tesla’s rocketing stock has meant an astonishing dive for investors who have staked their money on the proposition that Tesla shares were drastically overvalued and bound to fall. Their cost: $8.4 billion since January. These investors have been mostly losing the battle for years, as Tesla shares remained buoyant even as the electric-car manufacturer racked up billions of dollars in annual losses. Their pain has suddenly gone from chronic to acute as Tesla shares have soared to heights that few of its supporters would have ventured to predict. Last year, they lost $2.9 billion betting against Tesla. In the first week of February alone, they lost $2.4 billion as Tesla shares posted a string of multibillion-dollar daily gains, according to data from S3 Partners. Tesla reached its highest close on Feb. 4, at $887.06. Though shares slipped since then to close at $748.07 on Friday, the week saw a 15% gain, one of the best weeks for Tesla. Tesla shares have jumped nearly 79% since January.
Many of these investors are short-sellers, who borrow shares and sell them with the hope of profiting by buying the shares back at a lower price later and pocketing the difference.
Tesla CEO Elon Musk has made baiting the short-selling camp a prominent part of his prolific social media presence, which fans and detractors alike agree is a significant part of Tesla’s mystique. This past week, he tweeted three fire emojis as Tesla’s share price skyrocketed, which some speculated was a reference to how shorts were getting burned. One Twitter user responded: “You forgot to say something bullish about #bitcoin.”
In 2018, Mr. Musk tweeted that short sellers were “value destroyers” and that short sales should be illegal.
Tesla didn’t respond to requests for comment.
Adding to the short sellers’ financial toll is a psychic one: Tesla’s gains are driven in part by the short sellers’ pain—a “short squeeze,” in which rising prices force short sellers to purchase shares to close out losing wagers.
“Oh damn, I got my butt kicked,” was the thinking, said Robert Majteles, a private investor who rode Tesla’s swings up and down for years before being forced to close out his bearish position last week. “It’s the biggest set of losses that I’ve ever taken in 20 years.”
Shift in Sentiment
Tesla's short interest fell this year to itslowest level since 2010, when the stock begantrading.
Those losses have become other traders’ winnings, luring many more into the fray. Tesla has become one of the most popular stocks to trade ever. More than $55 billion worth of shares changed hands Tuesday, the most for a single stock since at least 1999. Options volumes have skyrocketed, as traders big and small look to profit from the car maker’s wild moves.
The stock has been volatile in the past, giving short-sellers windows to declare victory from time to time. Tesla shares slid to a low of $178.97 last June as worries grew about Mr. Musk’s ability to pull off his ambitious plans. They’re up about 320% since then.
The battle between Tesla believers and skeptics has captivated Wall Street. As Tesla shares went parabolic—the rare situation when the price chart of a widely held stock rises almost vertically over a period of days or weeks—traders recalled previous short-squeeze episodes, such as the battle over wireless standards that drove a 2,600% gain in Qualcomm Inc. in 1999.
In one sign of Tesla’s place in the zeitgeist, typing “should I” into a Google search recently prompted an autofill that read “should I buy Tesla stock.”
For almost every bullish investor, there is an equally passionate bearish one. Another popular Google query last week read, “should I short Tesla.”

Updating my initial forecast. I am assuming that Tesla will grow approximately 8% per year in line with the S&P 500. [1] I calculate the mean value by taking the three-month average of the closing price and multiplying this by 8%, pro rata-ed for what is left of the year. Economics do not currently favor electric vehicles (EVs), but political & environmental concerns do.  The huge sunk costs into internal combustion engine (ICE) technology has caused the global leaders in the automobile industry to react cautiously. I believe that Tesla is right about the growth prospects for EVs.  And VW/Toyota/GM could also be right to respond with caution, at least in the short run.  The North American EV market is still small compared to the market for large pickup trucks and SUVs, which is where GM and Ford earn their profits.  Only the high-end EVs can make money for carmakers, and Tesla dominates that segment.  While the established automakers would love to challenge Tesla, they do not want to compete on price.  Therein lies their dilemma. My bet is that the hesitation on the part of the established manufacturers will allow Tesla to prosper.
With Tesla being successful at automating more and more of the production and new products being produced in 2020 and 2021, I expect the profits will increase which will be reflected in stock price.

Just noticed this...
https://www.wsj.com/articles/can-tesla-hold-its-charge-11577892780 “Tesla Inc. TSLA 0.88% ended 2019 with a near-record valuation thanks to a nearly 70% rally in the stock price since late October. But investors should be careful not to confuse a buoyant stock price with a sustainably profitable business.
Fourth-quarter vehicle deliveries, expected later this week, might keep the momentum going. Analyst consensus calls for Tesla to deliver 106,000 cars in the quarter, according to FactSet. That would be a record for the electric auto maker and amount to roughly 17% unit growth from a year earlier. Wall Street analysts expect nearly $50 billion in annual revenue by 2022, which would be more than double 2019’s projected total.
Still, evidence abounds that Wall Street should curb its enthusiasm. Hitting that figure would mean Tesla barely met the low end of its 2019 guidance, which originally called for 360,000 to 400,000 deliveries. At the end of 2018, Tesla said it was selling vehicles at an annualized rate of 350,000. While record deliveries helped Tesla eke out a small third-quarter profit, total revenue fell by 8%. The car company has booked a cumulative net loss of more than $3 billion since sales of the Model 3 sedan began in 2017. Delivery figures should be flattered by the fact that Tesla began selling its Model 3 sedan in overseas markets in 2019. Tesla hasn’t traditionally broken out vehicle deliveries by country for investors, but U.S. automotive revenue fell by 40% from a year ago in the third quarter. The loss of federal tax credits for new Tesla buyers won’t help. Evidently fleeting interest from U.S. buyers should raise questions about how long current strength in markets like China or the Netherlands can persist. So should the introduction of more electric competitors. With the stock now trading above 70 times 2020 adjusted earnings estimates and worth twice as much as Ford Motor Co. , Tesla shareholders appear comfortable. That might prove an expensive bet to make.”

Tesla's average annual stock price increase over the past 5 years has been 20% so a decent base scenario is that the price will go up by a similar level this year - given the stock is currently around $400 that implies a strong probability of it being more than $400 a year from now. Nonetheless, the stock did decline during 2016 by around 11% which, if applied now, would put the stock between 350 and 400, a reasonable probability. The stock falling to lower than 250 would be a very significant decline - unlikely but not unheard of and slightly wider probability than might be expected because the 0-250 band is quite large.

Shanghai is really going to make a difference in profitability.
Tesla is over $400 today, so I needed to update my forecast. This is a crazy volatile stock, this will be a crapshoot for some time to come.

Tesla stock's implied volatility is currently around 40 percent (historical vol for last year is over 50).   To estimate what stock prices a normal distribution would imply in a year's time, one standard deviation +/- 40 percent covers 68 percent of the probability function.   Two standard deviations, +/- 80 percent, covers 95 percent. One annual standard deviation in the shares is about $140 (on a stock price of $375)   That means (if you believe Tesla's stock follows a normal probability distribution), there is a 16 percent probability that the stock will trade above $515 and a 16 percent probability the stock will close in a year below $235.   Most of the forecasters are imputing a very tight distribution centered around recent price activity, which means they are expecting a massive decline in measured volatility of Tesla stock.
currently trading $379, near all-time-high with resistance around this level since 2017.  2019 low was $177.  Growing competition and production problems are headwinds this year.

Tesla has approximately tracked the S&P 500 in terms of percentage gains over the last 5 years. The S&P 500 has increased by around 50% over 5 years so, very approximately, an estimate would be about a 10% increase over 1 year. This gives a Tesla estimate of around 380. There are several new models due out next year which may boost the price unless there's a disaster. Tesla have also qualified for subsidies in China which is likely to increase demand. Sales and revenue is up for the 9 months to Sep 2019 compared to Sep 2018. Cash is increasing. However, Musk is total liability. US federal subsidies have now ended. They have a lot of debt which could be an issue if sales falter - annual gross profit is approx 1/4 of total long term debt. Overall I reckon these things come up about even. Estimate is 380, but assuming a standard deviation of 20% of the price, so 66% of the variation is between around 310 and 450. The percentages above are a rough attempt to divide a normal distribution into those bands centered around 380.

I'll take the current price ($358 as of 12-14) as the base rate. It's trending mostly up for the past few months, but I feel like we could see some regression to the mean. They also had a recent crash, and stock prices seem to have fallen since that.

Tesla has been a wild series of good and bad news, but it's likely that the year will end with benign to positive developments in terms of projected total deliveries for 2019, pending orders, and China production. That should lift the stock a bit from current bc much of this news is a bit priced in already. But upside is muted due to limited trading at end of year. (https://www.fool.com/investing/2019/12/04/could-tesla-stock-rise-to-423.aspx, https://www.inc.com/justin-bariso/elon-musk-made-cybertruck-ugly-on-purpose-and-its-smartest-thing-hes-ever-done.html)

Using historic data on the tesla stock price from macrotrends.net. Basically compute daily returns from that data then take draws from that to estimate futures returns. The results give a bizarre prediction of huge tails and low in the center due to the high variance of tesla's stock returns so far. I'll trust the model right now given that we are so far out. Maybe the variance of their returns will continue going forward.

I'll narrow my error bars, only 385 days to go.  Fewer announcements more products would do TSLA stock price a favor. We are all pulling for Musk 'cause he is making a difference in our automotive future.

With the Cyber truck release and window issues, Tesla's hype-based news cycle provided a short term opportunity loss in cracking 350 and sustaining. With the recent Elon decision to refocus on solar panels, the company isn't shooting for short term gains, rather a longer term tend towards fiscal improvement. I assign smaller values to exceeding 350 due to a climate with tense Chinese-American relations of which Tesla components are built. However these are non zero due to President Trump's stock market hyper-aware Twitter feed generating positive sentiment despite negative trends.
They have potential for good news in very near term - plant in China, decent sales this year, Model Y coming up etc

As always, the problem for this company is to focus on what it's doing and avoid being sidetracked by the MuskRat's propensity to get on his horse and ride off in all directions at once.  Stay tuned.  And in the meantime if you happen to see an unbreakable pickup truck, don't throw anything harder than a snowball at it.

Slight tweak after looking a bit more closely at the percentiles.

I've generated a power law best fit for the past five years, which gives what looks to me like a fairly good fit, in relative terms (R^2= 0.25 which is not fantastic, but not horrible for 5 years of financial data with a simple trend line). Using the variability about that best fit trend, I get the following percentile projections, from which I have extracted my rough bounds:
0.01%: 200
0.1%: 205
1%: 218
10%: 259
20%: 295
30%: 329
40%: 346
50% (median, best guess): 364
60%: 384
70%: 399
80%: 415
90%: 435
99%: 481
99.9%: 491
99.99%: 492 This projection will need to be updated at, say, 9, 6, 3, 2 and 1 months out at least.

I'm going to make two forecasts. This first one will be superseded by another one shortly, but I want to show both approaches. The first thing I've done is looked at past data for the full period of record, then subsequent shorter periods and projected from a best fit linear trend of the data, from which I get:
9.5 yrs: 398
5 yrs: 332
3 yrs: 264
2 yrs: 204
1 yr: 182
6 mo: 576 These projections are all over the map, which is reflective of the fact that this is a very volatile stock.

(Its price has almost doubled since June low of $176. (https://www.investors.com/news/technology/tesla-stock-is-it-a-buy-now/))  Stock has traded above $250 since around mid-October 2019; YTD highest price is approx. $359 (on 11/19/19) (https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/TSLA/). TSLA stock price has recently rallied apparently in response to strong early ($100 minimum) deposits for Tesla 'Cybertruck' plus positive third quarter earnings: (https://www.fool.com/news/2019/11/25/tesla-stock-rises-after-cybertruck-orders-surpass.aspx, ) FWIW, analysts recently seem (mostly) split between buy-sell-hold for this stock (https://www.barrons.com/quote/stock/us/xnas/tsla/research-ratings, https://finance.yahoo.com/quote/TSLA/analysis?p=TSLA), though 'sells' may be dropping in November (per second linked source). Stock is currently trading well above its simple 200-day moving average.  ..Starting off with a fairly safe, 'generic' forecast, with a bias to the upside for 2020.
